texts.shortText: Small wader with a hunched appearance, short black bill, white belly and black markings on neck and chest. Perhaps best identified by the short, distinctively bright-orange legs. Intensity of plumage varies considerably with breeding condition. Breeding birds have mainly white head with intense black collar and bands, bright white chest and striking chestnut and black patches on wings. Non-breeding birds duller and more muted with darker head and less-obvious black markings.
Total length 21-25 cm, wingspan 50-57 cm, mass 85-150 g.

Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere in both Asia and Northern Europe. Summer migrants to coastal areas of Africa, Asia and Australia.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region.

Almost entirely coastal in their non-breeding range and found mostly on rocky shores, or on beaches where kelp or seagrass are deposited. Forages mostly by day in small, loose flocks, sometimes with other small waders such as Sanderlings. Has a characteristic feeding behaviour in which flips over stones or drift seaweeds with the strong neck and bill to access invertebrates hiding beneath.
Eats a diversity of invertebrates including gastropods, isopods and amphipods, polychaete worms and insect larvae.
Does not breed in South Africa, but in northern latitudes, where lay 2-5 eggs laid in a shallow scrape among vegetation or on stony or rocky ground.
The distinctive colour pattern and orange legs make this species unmistakable.
